notes: Inline planning dataset for Florida ports. Distances/times are approximate; show local traffic advisories in UI.

blurb: Tampa feels like an easy on-ramp to the Caribbean: compact cruise terminals, friendly logistics, and a waterfront that puts hotels, food, and the Riverwalk within simple reach. If you like calmer vibes than Miami and Port Everglades, Tampa’s your pace.

Arrive the day before, breathe, and enjoy Ybor City or the Riverwalk sunset. Getting to the terminals is straightforward, and rideshare works well. The channel can fog in on winter mornings, but the city’s hospitality (and cafés) make a delay feel civilized.
tips: Fly in a day early; Tampa runs smooth, but weather/ATC anywhere can ripple.
If driving, price compare port parking vs. hotel ‘park & cruise’ bundles.
Rideshare is cleanest for embark/debark; set pickup a block or two off the terminal for faster exits.
Hungry? Sparkman Wharf and Riverwalk are minutes from the cruise berths.
warnings: Winter AM fog (Dec–Feb) can slow channel transits; rare, but possible.
Rush hour (I-275, I-4, Selmon) 7–9am & 3:30–6:30pm can add 20–45 min.
Selmon Expressway has tolls; cashless. Ensure your rental has e-toll or use non-toll routes.
Spring Break surges (Mar–early Apr) + Gasparilla (late Jan) crowd hotels/roads.
College breaks: late Feb–Mar; K-12 breaks vary by district in Mar; Thanksgiving week and late Dec are heavy.

airports.name: Tampa International
airports.notes: Primary airport; frequent nonstops; excellent rideshare flow.

airports.name: St. Pete–Clearwater Intl
airports.notes: Budget carriers; allow extra time for weekend beach traffic.

airports.name: Sarasota–Bradenton
airports.notes: Small, easy airport; I-275/Skyway or I-75 + Selmon (tolls).

airports.name: Orlando Intl
airports.notes: Widest flight options; traffic + I-4 work zones can add time.

qa.q: Should I fly in the day of embarkation?
qa.a: We recommend flying in the day before. Tampa is efficient, but airline delays anywhere can echo. A quiet dinner on the Riverwalk beats sprinting to the gangway.

qa.q: Best budget way from TPA to the port?
qa.a: Rideshare is typically the simplest/cheapest for 1–3 people. For larger families, compare a private shuttle or hotel ‘park & cruise’ combos.

qa.q: Is fog a real issue here?
qa.a: Occasionally in winter mornings. Plans may adjust, but the line will communicate. Keep notifications on and keep breakfast flexible.

blurb: PortMiami is the world’s cruise crossroads: busy, polished, and built to move people. Expect big-ship energy, skyline views, and the widest selection of itineraries in Florida.
Traffic can be spirited. Padding your schedule is an act of peace. Arrive early, enjoy Brickell or Bayside, and let the port machinery whisk you aboard.
tips: Fly into MIA if possible; it’s the closest and has frequent nonstops.
Budget time for causeway backups on embarkation mornings and Sundays.
If you stay in Brickell/Downtown, a short rideshare beats renting a car.
Cruise day lunch: consider Brickell City Centre or Bayside to avoid crowds.
warnings: Rush hour + weekend cruise surges can double drive time to terminals.
Spring Break (early Mar–early Apr) is intense across Miami Beach/hotels.
Event spikes: Art Basel (early Dec), Ultra (late Mar), F1 (early May).
Tolls on causeways; ensure rental e-toll setup to avoid violations.

airports.name: Miami Intl
airports.notes: Closest/most flights; Metrorail + Brightline options nearby.

airports.name: Fort Lauderdale–Hollywood
airports.notes: Often cheaper fares; allow for I-95 traffic swings.

airports.name: Palm Beach Intl
airports.notes: Smaller airport; consider Brightline to MiamiCentral then rideshare.

qa.a: MIA is closest. FLL can be cheaper but plan 45–60+ min, more in rush hour. If arriving day-of, choose MIA.

qa.q: How early should I arrive at the terminal?
qa.a: Honor your assigned arrival window. Early is okay, but the smoothest check-in is inside your slot.

blurb: Port Everglades is the ‘efficient sibling’ of South Florida cruising—fast transfers, short hops from the airport, and terminals that keep lines moving.
Stay near 17th Street Causeway for painless embarkation day. With the beach and Las Olas close by, pre-cruise evenings feel like vacation already.
tips: FLL to port is usually 10–15 minutes; rideshare is easiest.
Hotels along 17th Street often offer shuttle bundles—price compare.
If flying into MIA, add I-95 buffer time or take Brightline to FLL.
warnings: Sundays stack multiple large-ship turnarounds; expect peak traffic.
Spring Break weeks spike hotel prices and beach traffic.
Drawbridge lifts on 17th St Causeway are brief but can bunch traffic.

airports.name: Miami Intl
airports.notes: More nonstops; consider Brightline to avoid I-95 swings.

airports.name: Palm Beach Intl
airports.notes: Smaller airport; works in a pinch.

qa.q: Is parking at the port worth it?
qa.a: It’s most convenient for short cruises. For a week, hotel ‘park & cruise’ bundles can pencil out better.

blurb: Port Canaveral blends cruise day with space-coast energy—clean terminals, easy road access, and beaches minutes away. It’s a favorite for families pairing Disney/Universal with a sailing.
Orlando (MCO) gives you flight choice; shared shuttles and private transfers make the 45–60+ minute trip simple if you build in time.
tips: If flying into MCO, aim to land before noon; earlier is calmer.
Shared shuttles are cost-effective; private cars win on time/comfort.
Staying in Cocoa Beach the night before removes I-95/I-528 stress.
warnings: I-528 (Beachline) weekend traffic can add 20–40 minutes.
Holiday weeks, Spring Break, and rocket launches surge hotel demand.
Afternoon thunderstorms (summer) can slow highway speeds.

airports.name: Orlando Intl
airports.notes: Most flight options; tolls on 528. Ensure rental e-toll or bring a SunPass.

qa.a: We advise the night before. If you must same-day, book an early morning arrival and nonstop. Weather and I-4 delays can stack quickly.

spring_break.notes: K-12 varies by district (most in March). Colleges peak early–mid March. Expect higher fares, crowded airports/interstates, and pricier hotels in port cities.

fall_break.notes: Adopted by some districts; modest but noticeable demand bump on Fridays/Mondays and long weekends.

other_spikes: Long weekends (MLK, Presidents’ Day, Memorial Day, Labor Day, Columbus/Indigenous Peoples’ Day, Veterans Day)

rendering_hints.distance_disclaimer: Times are typical in light–moderate traffic. Rush hour, events, weather, and incidents can extend travel.
